source 41_info_for_newly_diagnosed: # Who should I tell?

Who you decide to tell about your illness is completely up to you.
Perhaps a useful comparison is to the situation of having a physical
illness – if you had a physical illness that significantly affected
your life, who would you tell? The answer to this question may give
you an idea of who you should tell about having schizophrenia. It is
often a good idea to explain your condition to the people with whom
you have the closest relationships; for example, those you live with
and those you work closely with. It may not be necessary to tell
people who you do not have strong bonds with. Ultimately, everyone’s
situation is different, and only you will know what is best for your
own situation.

# Will I get better?

[show: statistics_on_who_gets_better.png] 1 in 5 people will recover
completely within 5 years. 3 in 5 people will improve, but may still
experience symptoms occasionally. 1 in 5 people will continue to have
troublesome symptoms.

There is a common misconception that people with schizophrenia have no
chance of recovery. This is not true: the symptoms of schizophrenia
can improve with appropriate treatment, and some people recover
completely. Recovery is a process that involves learning to manage
your symptoms, developing support systems and working towards your
goals. Appropriate ways to manage your condition with medication and
therapy are outlined in the next part of this guide.

¤:cite(["14_who_gets_schizophrenia", "21_causes", "41_info_for_newly_diagnosed"]):¤ Schizophrenia affects about 1 in 100 people and can affect anyone regardless of background. It is not your fault, and no one is to blame for developing it. Genetics and environmental factors can increase the risk, but they are not the sole causes. Notable individuals with schizophrenia have achieved great things, showing that the condition does not limit one's potential for success.

Regarding improvement, the manual mentions that with appropriate treatment, 1 in 5 people recover completely within 5 years, while 3 in 5 people will improve but may still have symptoms occasionally. 1 in 5 may continue to experience troublesome symptoms. Treatment typically involves medication, therapy, and support systems.

As for talking to someone, it depends on your comfort level and who you feel should know. Usually, people confide in those closest to them, like family or close coworkers.

Would you like more information on treatment options or how to communicate with loved ones about your condition?

What does it mean 3 in 5 people? Am I 3 in 5 people?

¤:cite(["41_info_for_newly_diagnosed"]):¤ The statement "3 in 5 people" refers to a statistic that indicates that out of every 5 people with schizophrenia, 3 might see an improvement in their symptoms with treatment, but they may still experience them occasionally. It is a general statistic and does not predict individual outcomes.

Whether you are one of those 3 in 5 people can't be determined solely by a statistic. Your experience with schizophrenia will be unique to you, including how your symptoms respond to treatment. It's important to work closely with your healthcare provider to develop a treatment plan tailored to your needs and to help you manage your symptoms effectively. Would you like to talk more about treatment and ways to improve your symptoms, or how to work with a healthcare provider for a plan that suits you?

¤:cite(["41_info_for_newly_diagnosed"]):¤ I apologize for any confusion. Let's simplify it: when doctors and researchers look at many people with schizophrenia, they notice that some people get completely better, some people get better but still have some symptoms sometimes, and some people still have symptoms that bother them a lot. They found that for every 5 people with schizophrenia:

- 1 person gets completely better in 5 years.
- 3 people get better, but might still have symptoms from time to time.
- 1 person might continue to have symptoms that are more difficult to manage.

This is just a general observation and does not tell us exactly what will happen to any one person, like you. Everyone is different, and your own chances of getting better depend on your situation, your body, and the treatment you get. It means there is hope and a possibility of improvement.
